snippet: Norman Seabrook’s long reign as president of the correction officers’ union has paid dividends for his members, but has also fed a culture of corruption and violence at the Rikers jail complex.
abstract: Norman Seabrook, powerful president of Correction Officers' Benevolent Assn union, has exerted enormous control over Correction Dept during his two-decade tenure; investigation by New York Times reveals that Seabrook's influence has fed culture of corruption and violence at Rikers Island jail complex, even as he protected union members, and has stalled attempted reforms.

byline.original: By MICHAEL SCHWIRTZ and MICHAEL WINERIP

lead_paragraph: Norman Seabrook’s long reign as president of the correction officers’ union has paid dividends for his members, but has also fed a culture of corruption and violence at the Rikers jail complex.

headline.main: At Rikers Island, Union Chief’s Clout Is a Roadblock to Reform
headline.print_headline: At Rikers, a Roadblock to Reform
